titleStmt.title: A proclamation touching the Kings Maiesties audit now shortly to be kept and holden at [blank] for the revenues of his highnesse crowne, within the countie of [blank] for the yeare ending at the feast of S. Michael the archangell now next comming. Anno Domini 162[blank]

notesStmt.note: Imprint information supplied from STC (2nd ed.).
Includes extra paragraph announcing Prince Charles's audit.

"Dated the [blank] day [blank] in the [blank] yeere of the raigne of our said most gracious Soueraign Lord Iames, by the grace of God king of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Defender of the faith &c."
Reproduction of original in: Society of Antiquaries.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Taxation -- Great Britain -- Early works to 1800.

div.head: ❧ A Proclamation touching the Kings Maieſties Audit now ſhortly to be kept and holden at 〈1 span left blank〉 for the Reuenues of his Highneſſe Crowne, within the Countie of _____ for the yeere ending at the Feaſt of S. Michael the Archangell now next comming. Anno Domini 162 _
div.p: WHere it is enacted by Authority of Parliament, that euery Auditor of the Reuenues of the Imperiall Crowne of this Realme, ſhall yeerly before the time of the Audit, cauſe Proclamations to be made in ſundry Market Townes, in euery County within the limits and circuit of their ſeuerall Offices, to the end that all and ſingular Receiuers, Bailiffes, Collectors, Reeues, Farmers, and other Occupiers, Officers, and Miniſters accountable, and all others whatſoeuer hauing to doe at that Audit, may the better be prepared with their Money, and all other things requiſite for the finiſhing and clearing of their accounts, as appertaineth.

Know ye therefore, that his Highneſſe Auditor of the ſaid Reuenues, within the county of _____ doeth by this preſent Proclamation, notifie and declare to all and ſingular Maiors, Sheriffes, Receiuers, Stewards, Vnderſtewards, Clarks of Courts, woodwards, Bayliffes, Collectors, Reeues, Farmers, and to all other the Kings Maieſties Officers and Subiects, that his Highneſſe Audit for his ſaid reuenues within the ſaid County of _____ for the yeere ending at the Feaſt of Saint Michael the Archangell now next comming, ſhall bee kept and holden at 〈1 span left blank〉 in the County of _____ and ſhall there begin vpon 〈1 span left blank〉 morning, the 〈1 span left blank〉 day of 〈1 span left blank〉 next.

Wherefore his Highneſſe ſaide Auditor, on his Maieſties behalfe, willeth and chargeth aſwell all and ſingular his Highneſſe Stewards, Vnderſtewards, and Clarkes of Courts, or their ſufficient Deputies, to be attendant at the ſaide Audit: and to bring thither with them, the Court Rowles belonging to their ſeuerall Offices, for the ſaid yeer and all other yeeres, whereof the profits be not yet anſwered. As alſo all & ſingular Receiuers, Woodwards, Bailiffes, Collectors, Reeues, Bedles, Farmers, and all other his Highnes officers, occupiers, and miniſters accountable, and all other his Subiects that owe to his Maieſty any arrerages, tenthes, rents reſerued, or other duties, to appeare at the ſaide Audit, then and there to yeeld account and make payment of the ſame and all other iſſues, commodities & profits due to his Highneſſe, within the ſaid County of _____ And to bring with them all Rentals, Letters Pattents Indentures, Leaſes, Coppies, and Extracts of Court Rowles, Warrants, Commiſſions, Tallies, Aquittances, and all other writings and things concerning any of the premiſes. And thereof not to faile, as they and euery of them, tender their duties towards his Highneſſe, and will auoid the forfaiture of their ſeuerall Fees and Offices, and other the penalties (by ſundry Statutes) limitted for puniſhment of all ſuch as doe not therein according to their duties. Dated the 〈1 span left blank〉 day 〈1 span left blank〉 in the 〈1 span left blank〉 yeere of the raigne of our ſaid moſt gracious Soueraigne Lord IAMES, by the grace of God King of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith &c.

Alſo at the ſame time & place the Audit for the moſt Noble Prince CHARLES, Prince of Wales, Duke of Cornewall, & Earle of Cheſter, is to be kept by the ſame Auditor, for his Highnes Poſſeſſions & Reuenues in the ſaid county of _____ for the ſame yeer. Whereof in like manner all his Highnes Stewards, Receiuers, Bailiffes, Farmers, Tenants, Officers & Miniſters, and all others to whom in that behalfe it doeth & may appertaine, are hereby required and admoniſhed to take knowledge and warning, and then and there likewiſe to appeare, yeeld accounts, and make payment of all Rents, Debts, duties and things due to his Highneſſe within the ſaid county. And in like manner to bring & ſhew forth all court rolles, Rent rolles, Letters patents, Indentures, Leaſes, copies, and Eſtreats of court rolles, Warrants, Commiſſions, Acquittances, and other Euidences, writings and things concerning any the premiſſes touching the Princes Highneſſe: and to tender and performe their duties towards his Highneſſe in that behalfe.
div.closer:
Dated the 〈1 span left blank〉 day of _____ in the 〈1 span left blank〉 yeere of the Reigne of our moſt gracious Soueraigne Lord IAMES, by the grace of God King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.
God ſaue the King.
